content.text: Neutropenic enterocolitis, also known as typhlitis, is a life-threatening condition characterized by inflammation of the cecum, appendix, and/or ileum. It typically occurs in severely neutropenic patients, particularly those undergoing chemotherapy for hematologic malignancies.

items: Abdominal pain, often in the right lower quadrant

content.text: Diagnosis is often made based on clinical suspicion in a neutropenic patient. CT scan of the abdomen is the imaging modality of choice and may show bowel wall thickening, pneumatosis intestinalis, or perforation.

Initial management is typically conservative and includes bowel rest, intravenous fluids, and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Surgery is reserved for patients with complications such as perforation, uncontrolled bleeding, or clinical deterioration despite medical management.

regimenData.notes: Antibiotic coverage should be broad and cover gram-negative, gram-positive, and anaerobic organisms. Consider adding antifungal coverage if the patient remains febrile.
